dublin_core.dcvalue: The neuropathological and cognitive changes preceding Alzheimer s disease AD appear to begin decades before disease symptoms make the clinical diagnosis obvious Clinical trials have begun to focus on preventive treatments aimed to slow cognitive decline in people with only subjective memory complaints However it is not clear how many years before clinical diagnosis of Alzheimer s disease is possible to recognize early signs of neurodegeneration We report evidence from the literature showing feasibility to diagnose AD at the stage of mild cognitive impairment MCI and also a few years before the MCI stage with imaging markers However we showed that neuroimaging brain changes evidenced decades before MCI are not early signs of neurodegeneration but expression of genetic risk states for AD or markers of inter individual variability of cognitive performance due to genetic or environmental factors
The journal of nutrition, health And aging
Imaging, subjective complaints, and MCI: 30 years before.
